content: Barry, to this day, remains a British Citizen. There is no proof he ever renounced his British citizenship. Furthermore, it's a popular myth amongst those who are familiar with this issue, that he somehow lost his British citizenship somewhere along the way. That's completely false, and Mario Apuzzo explains it well with facts (and citations from the Kenyan Constitution itself). A lengthy, but important read: "http://puzo1.blogspot.com/2009/04/obama-president-of-us-is-currently-also_07.html" The 'gist' of it is: quote: But neither Kenya’s independence from Great Britain nor the Kenyan Constitution caused Obama to lose his British citizenship with which he was born. ... There are no known statements from either Obama or his campaign contending that he eventually lost his British citizenship. Rather, the statements have been that his British citizenship converted to Kenyan citizenship when Kenya obtained its independence from Great Britain in 1963 and that he then lost Kenyan citizenship under the Kenyan constitution and laws when he did not renounce U.S. citizenship at age 21. But since Obama never lost his British citizenship, it does not matter that Obama may have lost his Kenyan citizenship as he contends. Therefore, as mentioned, we have a British citizen, sitting in the White House. "The bigger the government, the smaller the citizen."
quote: But neither Kenya’s independence from Great Britain nor the Kenyan Constitution caused Obama to lose his British citizenship with which he was born. ... There are no known statements from either Obama or his campaign contending that he eventually lost his British citizenship. Rather, the statements have been that his British citizenship converted to Kenyan citizenship when Kenya obtained its independence from Great Britain in 1963 and that he then lost Kenyan citizenship under the Kenyan constitution and laws when he did not renounce U.S. citizenship at age 21. But since Obama never lost his British citizenship, it does not matter that Obama may have lost his Kenyan citizenship as he contends.
reply: Barry, to this day, remains a British Citizen. There is no proof he ever renounced his British citizenship. Furthermore, it's a popular myth amongst those who are familiar with this issue, that he somehow lost his British citizenship somewhere along the way. That's completely false, and Mario Apuzzo explains it well with facts (and citations from the Kenyan Constitution itself). A lengthy, but important read: "http://puzo1.blogspot.com/2009/04/obama-president-of-us-is-currently-also_07.html" The 'gist' of it is:  Therefore, as mentioned, we have a British citizen, sitting in the White House. "The bigger the government, the smaller the citizen."
title: The British Citizen sitting in the White House!

Something he freely admitted to on his own campaign web site. 2. There is no known record of him renouncing his British citizenship, that again, he freely admitted to having. 3. When Kenyan gained independence from G.B., those with British citizenship (i.e. Barry), never lost it. It's right their in their own (Kenyan) Constitution. Some folks my choose to ignore this. Some folks may choose to remain indifferent. Some folks may believe that something like this only happens to other countries...that it couldn't possibly happen here. No way, not here. But that doesn't change the fact that he continues to be a British citizen to this day. "The bigger the government, the smaller the citizen."

content: quote: Originally posted by rangerdoug: quote: Originally posted by mfdaniels_rph: The British have always felt that anyone born a British citizen was always a British citizen. Isn't that one of the reasons for the war of 1812. The British were stopping American ships and taking American citizens by saying once a British citizen, always a citizen? Yes, but by the time war was declared the British had stopped that practice.[/QUOTE] I notice that Americans can be a bit cagey about what sort of trade many those US ships were engaged in. (That said the whole issue about Britain's unilateral enforcement of the 1808 Slave Trade ban has always reminded me of the zealous convert trying to assuage his guilt.) I certainly have the feeling that until 1808 many of those American Citizens and American Ships flew the Union Jack and hurriedly changed allegiance somewhere between Bristol and West Africa. As to whether he could claim British citizenship that's probably a bit murky, there were a couple of Acts that restricted the rights of Colonial and Commonwealth citizens to claim full British citizenship back in the Eighties (Thatcher was worried about several million Hong Kong Chinese suddenly rocking up before the 1997 handover). As I recall the right to say civis Britannicus sum was restricted to those who actually had ancestors from the UK and there were secondary tests even for them. Anyway even if he is we don't want him - or the rest of you for that matter - you're more trouble than you're worth.

Anyway even if he is we don't want him - or the rest of you for that matter - you're more trouble than you're worth.

However if you have some special knowledge that the entire Republican party, the CIA, the FBI and the US Supreme court, not to mention every media outlet in the world doesn't know about please step forward with unassailable proof and assure your place in history. If not, why not just drop it? How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
quote: Originally posted by rxsid4: quote: Originally posted by mfamily2004: Ditto the getting old part. He won. He's there. Get over it. This issue of allowing British (or Russian or Chinese or Spanish, etc) citizens to become our POTUS...will never get old.
reply: For crying out loud, I know we're supposed to be nice to newbies and also we're not allowed to make personal attacks. Let me see how I can express my self concerning your "theory" while being nice and not attacking you. title: The British Citizen sitting in the White House!

content: quote: Originally posted by rangerdoug: quote: Originally posted by mfdaniels_rph: The British have always felt that anyone born a British citizen was always a British citizen. Isn't that one of the reasons for the war of 1812. The British were stopping American ships and taking American citizens by saying once a British citizen, always a citizen? Yes, but by the time war was declared the British had stopped that practice.[/QUOTE] I notice that Americans can be a bit cagey about what sort of trade many those US ships were engaged in. (That said the whole issue about Britain's unilateral enforcement of the 1808 Slave Trade ban has always reminded me of the zealous convert trying to assuage his guilt.) I certainly have the feeling that until 1808 many of those American Citizens and American Ships flew the Union Jack and hurriedly changed allegiance somewhere between Bristol and West Africa. As to whether he could claim British citizenship that's probably a bit murky, there were a couple of Acts that restricted the rights of Colonial and Commonwealth citizens to claim full British citizenship back in the Eighties (Thatcher was worried about several million Hong Kong Chinese suddenly rocking up before the 1997 handover). As I recall the right to say civis Britannicus sum was restricted to those who actually had ancestors from the UK and there were secondary tests even for them. Anyway even if he is we don't want him - or the rest of you for that matter - you're more trouble than you're worth.

(That said the whole issue about Britain's unilateral enforcement of the 1808 Slave Trade ban has always reminded me of the zealous convert trying to assuage his guilt.) I certainly have the feeling that until 1808 many of those American Citizens and American Ships flew the Union Jack and hurriedly changed allegiance somewhere between Bristol and West Africa. As to whether he could claim British citizenship that's probably a bit murky, there were a couple of Acts that restricted the rights of Colonial and Commonwealth citizens to claim full British citizenship back in the Eighties (Thatcher was worried about several million Hong Kong Chinese suddenly rocking up before the 1997 handover). As I recall the right to say civis Britannicus sum was restricted to those who actually had ancestors from the UK and there were secondary tests even for them. Anyway even if he is we don't want him - or the rest of you for that matter - you're more trouble than you're worth.
title: The British Citizen sitting in the White House!

content: quote: Originally posted by rxsid4: Barry, to this day, remains a British Citizen. There is no proof he ever renounced his British citizenship. Furthermore, it's a popular myth amongst those who are familiar with this issue, that he somehow lost his British citizenship somewhere along the way. That's completely false, and Mario Apuzzo explains it well with facts (and citations from the Kenyan Constitution itself). A lengthy, but important read: "http://puzo1.blogspot.com/2009/04/obama-president-of-us-is-currently-also_07.html" The 'gist' of it is: quote: But neither Kenya’s independence from Great Britain nor the Kenyan Constitution caused Obama to lose his British citizenship with which he was born. ... There are no known statements from either Obama or his campaign contending that he eventually lost his British citizenship. Rather, the statements have been that his British citizenship converted to Kenyan citizenship when Kenya obtained its independence from Great Britain in 1963 and that he then lost Kenyan citizenship under the Kenyan constitution and laws when he did not renounce U.S. citizenship at age 21. But since Obama never lost his British citizenship, it does not matter that Obama may have lost his Kenyan citizenship as he contends. Therefore, as mentioned, we have a British citizen, sitting in the White House. Unfortunately, the same argument applies to everyone in the Original 13 Colonies, including George Washington... Britain has NEVER recognized a person's ability to give up British Citizenship. It would too easily unravel the Empire as they were and are . .. Wandering and Wondering
quote: Originally posted by rxsid4: Barry, to this day, remains a British Citizen. There is no proof he ever renounced his British citizenship. Furthermore, it's a popular myth amongst those who are familiar with this issue, that he somehow lost his British citizenship somewhere along the way. That's completely false, and Mario Apuzzo explains it well with facts (and citations from the Kenyan Constitution itself). A lengthy, but important read: "http://puzo1.blogspot.com/2009/04/obama-president-of-us-is-currently-also_07.html" The 'gist' of it is: quote: But neither Kenya’s independence from Great Britain nor the Kenyan Constitution caused Obama to lose his British citizenship with which he was born. ... There are no known statements from either Obama or his campaign contending that he eventually lost his British citizenship. Rather, the statements have been that his British citizenship converted to Kenyan citizenship when Kenya obtained its independence from Great Britain in 1963 and that he then lost Kenyan citizenship under the Kenyan constitution and laws when he did not renounce U.S. citizenship at age 21. But since Obama never lost his British citizenship, it does not matter that Obama may have lost his Kenyan citizenship as he contends. Therefore, as mentioned, we have a British citizen, sitting in the White House.
reply: Unfortunately, the same argument applies to everyone in the Original 13 Colonies, including George Washington... Britain has NEVER recognized a person's ability to give up British Citizenship. It would too easily unravel the Empire as they were and are . .. Wandering and Wondering
title: The British Citizen sitting in the White House!
